bibl.title: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, April 26, 1900

div1.p: Louise Kean writes about quarantine and sanitation rules for yellow fever in Cuba, Jefferson Randolph Kean's work in Havana, and her plans to leave Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, April 26, 1900
div1.p:
I was so glad
to get your letter of
the 21st yesterday, for
my last news of you
was your letter of the
12th. I have been quite
worried about you, and
was watching most
anxiously for a letter
telling me how you were,
and I really think one
of those good-for-nothing
girls might have sent
me a line on the subject.

None of the things
have come yet, but I
think they are all on
the transport that is
in today. Your blue
skirt will do finely
for my trip north, and
it is very good of you
to give it to me. Do
keep my new dress safe
at home, for I have no
earthly use for it, and
it sounds as if it were
very pretty. I am sorry
to say that yesterday, before your
letter came I gave my pink divinity to
Rufinia's daughter to make up for
me. You see I did not know what
you had sent me, or if I could
have the seamstress as soon as I
arrived, and, as I had planned to
go to Molly so soon. I was afraid to
wait any longer lest I should slip
up at both ends of the line, and, as
I have so few clothes I was afraid
to risk it. However I shall need
the woman to make me one or two
simple evening dresses, for I have none
at all, and some matinee's. I guess
we can plan those when I get home
tho', and if this little French girl
turns out to be of any account, she
can make up one or two more things
for which I have the material.
I wonder if I will
get my cape, for I have
no wrap at all. Mrs.
Lee has kindly offered
me an extra cape she
has, if mine does not
arrive, but I trust you
will get it on the
Sedgewick as I suggested
in my last letter.
The quarantine does not
go on until the 16th,
and, even if we did
not get away before
then, we would not
have to be out five
days, for there are a few
nice, clean places in
Cuba which will be
excepted from that rule
for some time, and, of
course, Quemados is one
of them. So we will be
neither fumigated or
detained.

Rannie is dreadfully
busy now, with his or-
phans and civil hospitals
and the first of the
month he is on the
board to examine can-
didates for the regular corps. Which
is very annoying, as he will have
to spend a large part of his time
in town the last few days I am
here.

May Myrick lunched with me yester-
day. They are planning to spend
the summer. Tonight Rannie and
I dine with the Heards.

Martha is very well, and getting more
resigned to the idea of her voyage,
tho' we cannot persuade her she
will not be sick. When the things
come from the transport I will write
again. I hope you are not still laid
up with that wretched cold, dear Mumsie
